BjÃ¶rkâ€™s music provides a framework for fragmented stories. A lone fisherman provides a ghost of a narrative and, because BjÃ¶rkâ€™s music often references nature, a link to the natural world. Woven around the fishermanâ€™s tale are snippets of love stories. Ultimately, Pita explains, BjÃ¶rk Ballet is about â€œbirth, life, sex, and death.â€  Throughout ğ˜‰ğ˜«Ã¶ğ˜³ğ˜¬ ğ˜‰ğ˜¢ğ˜­ğ˜­ğ˜¦ğ˜µ, Pitaâ€™s choreography for its twenty-two dancers mixes kicks, lunges, and squats with classically inspired technique. In trying to capture BjÃ¶rkâ€™s essence, Pita goes to extremes with his movement. There are cantilevered duets with an underwater quality and a classically based octet, set to ğ˜ğ˜³ğ˜°ğ˜´ğ˜µğ˜ª, that Pita says, â€œshould look like a ballerina music box on acid.â€ ğ˜ğ˜ºğ˜±ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜£ğ˜¢ğ˜­ğ˜­ğ˜¢ğ˜¥, Pitaâ€™s ballet rave, entails a long jumping sequence set to a pumping, driving rhythm. â€œItâ€™s a metaphorâ€”jumping for joy, jumping for love,â€ says Pita.
